content.caption: Renewables & Storage KPI Cheat Sheet

content.content:
## Talk track (fast)

- Start with the bill: **energy charges + demand charges + TOU**
- Solar offsets kWh; storage reduces peaks and shifts energy
- Bundle with EE first to reduce required system size
- Incentives and tax credits often drive ROI‚Äîlock eligibility early

**One-liner:** "We design around your tariff: solar reduces energy cost, storage reduces peaks, and incentives improve payback."

## What to verify (fast)

- Interval data: load shape and demand windows
- Roof and electrical constraints (service size, spare capacity)
- PV shading and structural constraints
- Storage dispatch objectives (demand, TOU, backup)
- Interconnection rules and export limits

**Rule:** economics are tariff-driven; get interval data and tariff early.

## What to capture on-site

- Roof type, age, and obstructions (HVAC, skylights)
- Electrical room photos: main service, panel space, transformer
- Parking lot layout (for carports/EV)
- Any generator/backup needs and critical loads
- Space for batteries (clearances, ventilation, fire code constraints)

# Why Renewables & Storage Matter

Renewables and storage can reduce operating costs and emissions, but the value depends on:

- **Tariffs** (energy vs demand charges, TOU)
- **Interconnection** (export limits and timelines)
- **Load shape** (when the building uses power)
- **Incentives** (tax credits, rebates, state programs)

Storage adds flexibility: it can reduce peaks, shift energy, and provide resiliency if designed for backup.

sections.title: Rooftop Solar PV
sections.subtitle: Basics of PV systems on commercial roofs

content.content:
## Rooftop PV basics

Key constraints:
- Roof age and remaining life (avoid installing on a roof that needs replacement)
- Structural capacity
- Shading from rooftop equipment
- Electrical interconnection point and available capacity

**Field tip:** if the roof is within ~5 years of replacement, plan a coordinated re-roof + PV project.

## Carport and ground-mount

Carports add value beyond energy:
- Shade and weather protection
- EV-ready infrastructure

Ground-mount is rare in dense commercial but can work for campuses and industrial sites with land.

sections.title: Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS)
sections.subtitle: Demand shaving, TOU shifting, and backup

content.content:
## What batteries do

- **Demand charge reduction**: discharge during peak demand
- **TOU arbitrage**: charge off-peak, discharge on-peak
- **Backup**: support critical loads during outages (requires design)

Key specs:
- Power (kW) and energy (kWh)
- Round-trip efficiency
- Warranty and cycling limits

**Sales translation:** batteries pay when the tariff has demand or high TOU peaks‚Äîor when resiliency has value.

content.caption: BESS use case fit

content.content:
## Drivers of ROI

- Energy offset value (kWh √ó $/kWh) based on tariff/NEM
- Demand charge reduction (kW shaved √ó $/kW)
- Incentives (tax credits, rebates)
- Project cost (EPC, interconnection, soft costs)

**Rule:** solar ROI is often energy-based; storage ROI is often demand/TOU-based.

## Tariff basics

Commercial bills commonly include:
- **Energy charges** ($/kWh)
- **Demand charges** ($/kW) based on peak demand
- **Time-of-use** (TOU) pricing

Net metering/export rules determine how exported solar is compensated.

**Sales translation:** a good design starts with the tariff and interval data‚Äînot panel count.

## EV + solar/storage

EV charging can add large coincident load and increase demand charges.

Best practices:
- Managed charging (load sharing)
- Off-peak scheduling
- Storage to cap peaks (site-specific)

**Rule:** design EV as a managed load, not a passive plug.

sections.title: Behind-the-Meter Strategy
sections.subtitle: Designing for the meter, not the brochure

content.content:
## Behind-the-meter (BTM) concept

BTM projects are optimized to reduce the customer‚Äôs bill. The best portfolio strategy often is:

1) Efficiency (reduce baseline)
2) Solar (offset energy)
3) Storage (reduce demand/shift TOU)
4) Managed EV (prevent new peaks)

**Sales translation:** bundling improves ROI and avoids oversizing.

# Selling Renewables & Storage

## Positioning

- Bill reduction: energy + demand
- Incentive stacking: tax credits and local programs
- Resiliency: if the customer values backup

### Discovery questions
- What tariff are you on and how large are demand charges?
- Do you have interval data available?
- Are there upcoming roof replacements or site constraints?
- Any EV expansion plans?
- Is backup/resiliency a priority?

### Objection handling
| Objection | Response |
|---|---|
| "Solar ROI isn‚Äôt what it used to be" | "It depends on your tariff and export rules‚Äîwe model your actual bill." |
| "Batteries are expensive" | "They pay when demand charges and TOU peaks are high; we target the peak windows." |
| "Interconnection takes too long" | "That‚Äôs why we start interconnection early and phase the project with EE and controls in parallel." |

## Incentives overview

Common incentive categories:
- Federal tax credits (ITC) and adders (project-dependent)
- State programs (e.g., storage incentives)
- Utility programs (site-specific)

**Rule:** eligibility and documentation requirements should be checked early‚Äîbefore equipment selection is finalized.

questions.question: For many commercial customers, what bill component often makes batteries valuable?
questions.explanation: Batteries often pay by reducing demand charges and shifting energy away from high TOU periods.

questions.question: Why is interval data important for solar + storage modeling?
options: It reveals load shape and peak timing
questions.explanation: Interval data shows when the building uses power and when peaks occur‚Äîcritical for dispatch economics.

questions.question: What is a common project schedule risk for solar projects?
questions.explanation: Interconnection approvals and constraints can dominate schedule and scope.

questions.question: What is a typical battery round-trip efficiency range?
questions.explanation: Many commercial battery systems are roughly ~85‚Äì92% round-trip efficient depending on equipment and operating range.

questions.question: Why is a bundled EE + solar + storage approach often recommended?
options: It reduces required system size and improves ROI
questions.explanation: Efficiency reduces baseline usage and peaks, allowing smaller PV/storage and better economics.
